div1.p: Dear John: — How good to hear from you and to learn of your safe arrival. And my, how you are in demand — New York, Ithaca, The Poetry Society. I think that is wonderful. Perhaps then touches with explain you. As Antaeus touched the earth & drew from it reviving strength, so perhaps all these contacts buoy you up.

Now I must tell you of the impression you made here. At the opening of my first class after you recited, I got all sorts of questions about you. They were clearly greatly interested. Prof. Golden told me too, how much his students appreciated you, & how pleased he was that you could take them for a period just as if you had been teaching them right along, & give then exactly what they needed.

I heard any number of favorable comments on your public lecture. My assistant, Russell Moran, made one of the most interesting observations. He noted that late in my class & in the public lecture, the people were leaning back in their seats at the start, but then as you talked they leaned forward.

Reverend Christie said that he believed the part of Sitting Bull dealing with the behavior of his horse is the first thing of its kind in English literature: Then he said something else the like of which I have never heard before. He is allergic to horses. They bring on a sort of asthma. As you recited, he felt a recurrence of his asthma. How's that for reality!

Nita & I were so glad to have you in the house as our guest. And you always do so much for my spirit. How grateful I am for that day spent on my manuscript. I wrote to Clarkson Potter, & he asked me to read the mss to him. Maybe he won't take it, but when it has such strong approval from you, I should feel like trying some more.
If you should go to New York, or some other eastern point, be sure to stop with us on your return. As used to be said in olden times to a dear friend, the latch string is always out for you
